body: Bumper Cars Cobble Hill is a neighborhood of old brownstones and narrow streets. It also has a hospital and nursing home whose employees often wait in their cars and save spaces for friends on the next shift -- an annoying but not illegal practice. What must be illegal, though, is cramming one's car into too small a space. Having witnessed this one
title: COMPLAINT BOX; And Another Thing...

body: THERE are many spectacles in New York every December, from the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center to Bergdorf Goodman's fantastical windows. But of special interest are the holiday markets that pop up all over the city, from Grand Central Terminal to Union Square, with hundreds of artisans and retailers selling unusual gifts. One of them is Lotta
title: SHOPPING WITH LOTTA ANDERSON; Handy for the Holidays

title: The Listings

body: At a time when many people are cursing the economy, David Alhadeff, the owner of the Future Perfect, has reason to be grateful to it. Thanks to the reduced rents, he was recently able to open a Manhattan outpost of his Brooklyn design store, which will carry mostly contract and high-end residential furnishings. The space has a distinctly industrial
title: CURRENTS | OPEN; The Future Perfect Plants Its Flag in Manhattan

body: Firefighters found two men dead in a van that had caught fire in Brooklyn on Friday near the Gowanus Expressway. The victims, whose names and ages were not released, were found just before 9 p.m. after people in the area noticed that the van was on fire and called 911. Firefighters found the bodies after they pried open the doors and extinguished
title: 2 Found Dead in a Van in Sunset Park

body: It was drizzling lightly in late October when the midnight shift started at the Owls Head Water Pollution Control Plant, where much of Brooklyn's sewage is treated. A few miles away, people were walking home without umbrellas from late dinners. But at Owls Head, a swimming pool's worth of sewage and wastewater was soon rushing in every second.
title: Sewers at Capacity, Waste Poisons Waterways

body: ''MONEY is no object when it comes to punk rock,'' said Thurston Moore, the frontman for Sonic Youth. He was flipping through stacks of vinyl at Academy Records in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with Jemina Pearl, his latest protégé, who had just unearthed a first pressing of ''Raw Power'' by Iggy and the Stooges, from 1973. ''But it's $40,'' she
title: A NIGHT OUT WITH | JEMINA PEARL; Punk's Fresh Face

body: Once it might have seemed a match made in zoning heaven: a concrete plant dropped into gritty, tumbledown Red Hook. But Red Hook, a western Brooklyn peninsula known for its rough-hewn docks and their denizens, has been cultivating a gentler, more genteel image for years now, becoming a magnet for artists looking for cheap space, homesteaders
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; Dust Has Yet to Settle Over New Concrete Plant

body: Less than two years ago, the Brooklyn Brewery found itself in a bind that had squeezed many companies out of New York. It wanted to expand, but the rapid gentrification of its neighborhood, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had pushed rents beyond what it could afford. That was before the recession took hold in the city. Now, the brewery is taking
title: Soft Real Estate Market Is a Key Ingredient at Brooklyn Brewery

title: The Listings

author: Andrew Rice is a contributing writer for the magazine.
body: THE GOWANUS CANAL runs one and a half miles through brownstone Brooklyn, cutting a disreputable gash between two of the most desirable residential neighborhoods in New York City. Sunken below street level, no more than 100 feet across at most points, the canal does not really flow -- it skulks. On sunny days, its waters take a greenish hue and are
title: RENEWAL; ON THE WATERFRONT

body: He has dreamed of windmills atop skyscrapers, planted magnolia trees with Bette Midler and basked in the effusive praise of Al Gore. More than any mayor before him, Michael R. Bloomberg has made the environment a central theme in his vision of urban life -- a surprising turn for a man who is a billionaire known mainly for his business savvy when he
title: Mayor's Environmental Record: Grand Plans and Small Steps Forward

body: BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real
title: When Love Is a Schlep

body: Suzanne Fiol, an impresario of avant-garde culture in New York, who founded the performance space Issue Project Room and served as its artistic rudder, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 49 and lived in Brooklyn. The cause was cancer, said Sarah Garvey, a spokeswoman. Opened in 2003 in a former garage in the East Village, Issue Project Room
title: Suzanne Fiol, 49, Avant-Garde Impresario

body: REUBEN COPE, a lanky Irish artist, unpacked his bag of broken objects: a few inches of knitting pocked with dropped stitches, a ceramic sherry label broken in half, an adaptor for his razor. Mr. Cope, who lives in a castle in Kilkenny, was in town visiting his girlfriend; he announced that he had tried knitting and yoga for the first time the day
title: SEEN; The Art Of the Repair

body: AFTER 37 years in their house on Dean Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, Norman and Roselyn Kopit decided last summer that it was finally time for a change of scene. title: LIVING IN | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; Subway Lines Galore, but Who's Leaving?

body: Over the decades, Red Hook, Brooklyn, has been home to many things: a brawny, corrupt waterfront; free-range prostitution; a sprawling housing project once pocked by drugs and gunfire; artists seeking space and the hunters of cool who inevitably follow them. title: A High-Tech Home for Multimillion-Dollar Works of Art

body: BEAUTY is more powerful when it's unexpected. Like the garden on Union Street, right by the drawbridge to the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, where shuttered warehouses meet the cracked, treeless cement. Eight-foot sunflowers tower over the graffiti on the warehouse wall. Larkspur and lavender, bee balm and verbena, clematis and sweet alyssum bloom
title: IN THE GARDEN; Growing Cottage Flowers In Gowanus

body: The only thing cooler than a pool party on a summer night in New York City is a secret pool party. And the only thing cooler than that, as a few enterprising developers recently discovered, is a secret pool party in a pool made out of a Dumpster on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in industrial Brooklyn. On a rented lot that's hidden from the street
title: Forget the Trash Bag, Bring a Towel

body: When it comes to the avant-garde side of the arts, the numbers tend to be pretty small. Record sales of a thousand or two, if you're lucky; theater audiences in the dozens, not hundreds. But last year Issue Project Room, a nonprofit arts space that was founded in the East Village and for the last four years has been in Brooklyn, was dealt a
title: An Avant-Garde Arts Group Bites Off a Lot to Chew

body: AN artist without a gallery can take to the streets. But what's a chef without a restaurant to do? You can run a speakeasy operation in your apartment and hope no one tells the health inspectors. Or you can find an existing restaurant and stage a coup (politely), as a few young cooks in Brooklyn have done. BEP At Simple Café, 346 Bedford Avenue
title: $25 AND UNDER; Raiding the Kitchen

body: Who needs Renoir's barges on the Seine? Jose Gaytan is enraptured by scows on the Gowanus. Almost every day for the past six years, Mr. Gaytan, with his two dogs, has crisscrossed the streets and bridges near the Gowanus, Brooklyn's famous canal, photographing moments of serenity, color and beauty amid the decaying postindustrial landscape.
title: By the Gowanus, A Painterly Lens On the Ruins Amid a Rebirth

body: New York City is well-known for dense skyscrapers and gritty neighborhoods, but it also has 578 miles of coastline. Some of that coastline is also gritty (Gowanus, anyone?), but there are plenty of peaceful and pristine spots. title: SNAPSHOT |COASTLINE; Sand, Surf and Shoobies

body: Fighting to prevent the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn from being labeled a Superfund site, city officials are proposing an alternative cleanup plan that they say would still be overseen by the Environmental Protection Agency but would take only about half the time a Superfund project would require. title: City Proposes New Plan for Gowanus Canal Cleanup

body: LONDON -- Recession has jarred the world of contemporary art as much as any part of the economy, but for art, the shake-up may turn out to be inspirational. A wave of small-scale, independent initiatives is leading a shift from self-referential conceptualism and production-line output toward a rediscovery of accessibility and classical skills.
title: SPECIAL REPORT: CONTEMPORARY ART; Getting Creative in a Downturn

body: The Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is notoriously toxic. Since 1869, the mile-long waterway has been a dumping ground for sewage, industrial sludge, guns and body parts -- its waters once too vile to search. Today you can still stand on a bridge over the canal and see unmentionables floating on an iridescent film. The odor, once almost unbearable, has
title: EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK; From Gowanus to Venice

body: Either/Or, the new-music ensemble formed in 2004 by the composer and pianist Richard Carrick and the percussionist David Shively, is devoted to a species of avant-garde composition in which concepts like tonality, serialism and Minimalism are beside the point. This is a world where pure sound and texture are of greater interest than form and
title: MUSIC REVIEW | EITHER/OR; Ensemble That Plays By Its Own Rules

body: FOR $1,000 a month, most New Yorkers expect to rent little more than a tiny cramped space devoid of light and charm. But recent graduates with budgets under $1,000 can easily find suitable apartments in Brooklyn or Queens, and real estate agents say that in the current market, $2,000 is even enough for a two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan south of
title: Not a Dive After All

body: THEY said nothing could replace Mooney's Pub. For almost a year, they were right. The old bar, which had stood on Flatbush Avenue near Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights since before Brooklyn was fashionable, closed in a rent dispute last June, after a rollicking Saturday night when the air-conditioning broke and people crowded in anyway. The next
title: DISPATCHES; A Bar -- a Bar! -- Where the Pub Used to Be

body: Pop Jon Pareles Death is a fact of life in ELVIS PERKINS's songs. body: On a warm Saturday morning, Jose Ilarraza stood by the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn watching two yellow cranes on the other side digging into mountains of scrap metal and dumping it onto a barge. title: On the Gowanus Canal, Fear of Superfund Stigma

body: IN the summer of 1992, I was 21 and it cost $1.25 to ride the subway. The Soviet Union had been dead for nearly a year, and from the window of the F train heading from the Kensington section of Brooklyn into the city, I peered at the Lower Manhattan skyline and beyond it to my lost home across the ocean. I was a Lot's wife in pants. Those were
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Call of Kiev

body: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed to add the Gowanus Canal, in Brooklyn, to its list of Superfund sites, a step that advocates hope will revitalize a waterfront hobbled by environmental problems from its industrial past. title: Gowanus Canal, Polluted for Many Decades, May Become Superfund Site

body: WHEN Whitney Pettyjohn and her 19-year-old sister, Chelsey, moved to Brooklyn last August, the best deal they could find in their price range was a two-bedroom in Bushwick with unreliable heat, nine blocks from the Morgan Avenue stop on the L train. title: Why Are These Renters Smiling?

body: MY NEIGHBOR JOE EMBRACED THE ZEITGEIST, or was embraced by it, shortly before Thanksgiving a couple of years ago when he decided to bid adieu to his S.U.V., a two-and-a-half ton specimen that was a pain to park, got only slightly better mileage than a cement mixer and bore a brand name that meant to evoke, through misspelling, a famously resilient
title: Share My Ride

body: Along with about 80 other girls from Harlem high schools, Nikkita McPherson, 18, sifted through racks of formal dresses on Saturday afternoon, looking for just the right one to wear to her senior prom. ''I'm hoping to find something very nice, but unique and simple,'' said Ms. McPherson, the senior class president at Frederick Douglass Academy.
title: So Long, Bridesmaid; Hello, Prom Queen

body: TO get the slightly battered convection oven for their new Brooklyn chocolate factory, Rick and Michael Mast traded 250 chocolate bars. The chocolate is as good as legal tender for Andrew Tarlow and Mark Firth, owners of Marlow & Sons, the restaurant and specialty shop that bartered away the oven. ''We can't keep it in stock,'' Mr. Tarlow said.
title: Now in Brooklyn, the 19th Century

body: The M/V North River, a twin-screw tanker out of Brooklyn, steamed past Rikers Island, swung to port, then slipped into its mooring in Hunts Point, in the Bronx. A deckhand tied the ship off while another hooked its hoses to a manifold. Above decks, in the bridge, the first mate took the signal, then gently depressed a switch. With a hum of quiet
title: ROOMS; Where the Sea Air Meets Its Match

body: YEARS of mental preparation for this fateful day don't make it any less poignant or bittersweet. I've loaded the minivan with the entirety of the 10-year existence of Jack, our firstborn: duffel-bagged wardrobe, a deflated soccer ball, a tattered Tickle Me Elmo doll and an oversize stroller. Last in is his clunky wooden Swedish-made feeding chair,
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Smiling Jack

body: When the singer-songwriter Schuyler Fisk was 17, she up and moved from Charlottesville, Va., to Los Angeles to pursue a career as an actor. That's partly because her parents not only understood the impulse, but had also lived

body: THERE are certain things that people moving into the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn need to know if they hope to get by. If your vehicle is parked next to the curb, it will without warning be blocked in by a row of double-parked cars during street-cleaning hours. title: LIVING IN | CARROLL GARDENS, BROOKLYN; Brio Inside the Brownstones

body: THE little Borden Avenue Bridge has spanned the narrow waters of Dutch Kills, a tributary of Newtown Creek, for more than a century. But unlike its more heralded peers of similar endurance, this bridge tends not to attract tourists. It is in the industrial neighborhood of Sunnyside, Queens, under an elevated section of the Long Island Expressway,
title: SUNNYSIDE; A Humble Bridge With One Fetching Feature

author: Gabriel Cohen is the author of four Brooklyn-based novels, including ''Neptune Avenue,'' to be published in May.
body: THE boy was young, perhaps 3 or 4, and he stood inside the front window of a Park Slope sexual aid emporium, holding what appeared to be an adult toy. title: You Talkin' to Me?

body: Self-awareness has always been a life-giving force in the reedier marshes of indie-rock. For Okkervil River, from Austin, Tex., it also borders on an obsession. title: MUSIC REVIEW | OKKERVIL RIVER; On a Bumpy Road to Stardom, Insight in a Trail of Dashed Illusions

body: IT was an especially cacophonous ''Auld Lang Syne.'' But for the Knitting Factory's last night in Manhattan, it was appropriate, as the shaggy avant-folk group Akron/Family led a version of that Scottish New Year's hymn on Wednesday night that mutated from a simple singalong to screeching feedback to a meditative one-note drone. title: Out With The Knit, In With The Wine
